image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives About this object

profileText: a Representative from New York; born in Brooklyn, N.Y., November 27, 1869; attended the public schools of his native city and was graduated from the law department of New York University, New York City, in 1895; was admitted to the bar the following year and commenced the practice of his profession in New York City; elected as a Democrat to the Sixtieth and Sixty-first Congresses (March 4, 1907-March 3, 1911); was not a candidate for renomination in 1910; convicted on January 24, 1914, of bribery; full pardon by New York Governor Charles Seymour Whitman on January 24, 1918; engaged in the real estate business; died in New York City, February 12, 1938; interment in Evergreen Cemetery, Brooklyn, N.Y.

researchRecord.name: 1911, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: Correspondence from William Willett to Belle Greene written on September 19 and October 4, 1911. In the correspondence, Willett writes about a memorial window at West Point.

researchRecord.name: 1912, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: Correspondence from William Willett to an unidentified recipient on Nov. 15, Jan. 2, 5, 6, 8, 1912. In the correspondence, Willett writes about design for a window to be considered for St. George's.
